translation (mimeographed) by Eva V. Bayoneta (Manila, Bureau 
of Public Schools, 1959). Fr. Tomas Santaren’s Spanish transla¬ 
tion of the Bornean story was translated into English by Enri- 
queta Fox, Sarawak Museum Journal, Volume 7, No. 7, 1956. 
Tom Harrison’s “Bisaya: Bomeo-Philippine Impacts of Islam” 
and R. A. Bewsher’s “Bisayan Accounts of Early Bornean Settle¬ 
ment in the Philippines Recorded by Father Santaren,” Sarawak 
Museum Journal, Volume 7, No. 7, 1956, supplement the ac¬ 
counts concerning the Bornean datus. 
On races in the Philippines and Southeast Asia, the following 
may be consulted: Manuel Anton’s articles in the section “Antro- 
pologia,” in Exposicion Filipina (Madrid, 1887), H. Otley Beyer’s 
Population of the Philippine Islands in 1916 (Manila, 1916), David 
Barrows’ article in the Census of 1903, Volume I, Ferdinand Blu- 
mentritt’s “List of Native Tribes,” Report of the Smithsonian 
Institution, 1897, Rudolf Virchow’s “The Peopling of the Philip¬ 
pines,” reprinted in Craig’s The Philippines Through Foreign 
Eyes (Manila, 1916), and a few others, such as Alfred Wallace, 
L.R. Sullivan, Montano, Sanchez, Hose and McDougal, and Baring- 
Gould and Bampfylde, whose works are difficult to come by in 
the Philippines today. 
CHAPTER III 
Philippine culture before the coming of the Spaniards has been 
described by many authors, particularly Spanish. The most 
important ones, considered as standard references, are Francisco 
Colin’s Labor Evangelica (Madrid, 1663), edited and annotated 
by Pablo Pastells (Barcelona. 1900-1902) in three volumes; the 
English version of Colin is found in Blair and Robertson’s The 
Philippine Islands (Cleveland, 1903-1908), Volume 40; Juan de 
Plasencia’s Las Costumbres de los Tagalos (ca. 1589), in Blair and 
Robertson, Volume 7; Miguel de Loarca’s Relacion de las Islas 
Filipinas, in Blair and Robertson, Volume 16. Another English 
version, the first, is found in Sir Henry of Alderley (Henry E.J. 
Stanley), published in London in 1868 as a volume in the Hakluyt 
Society Series. Rizal’s edition of Morga (1890) is inferior to 
that of Retana. The works of such priests as Santa Ines, Delgado, 
San Agustin, and others, are helpful but not easily available. 
For available secondary sources, Josue Soncuya’s Historia Pre- 
Hispana de Filipinas (Manila, 1917) is good; it d^cusses the early 
history and customs of the Visayans, particularly those of the 
island of Panay. A brief but perceptive study of the ancient

Filipino culture and society is found in Robert B. Fox’s “Pre¬ 
historic Foundations of Contemporary Filipino Culture and 
Society,” Comment, First Quarter, No. 5, 1958, and in the same 
author’s The Philippines in Pre-Historic Times. For an anthro¬ 
pological approach to Filipino culture, see F. Landa Jocano’s 
“Rethinking Filipino Cultural Heritage,” in Lipunan, Vol. 1, No. 1 
(1965), pp. 53-71. The same author’s Questions and Challenges 
in Philippine Prehistory (Quezon City, University of the Philip¬ 
pines, 1975) disputes Beyer’s theory of Malay migrations to the 
Philippines and sets forth his own theory. Jocano’s theory appears 
to have a better basis than the hitherto accepted theory of the 
late H. Otley Beyer. The early religions of the Filipinos are dis¬ 
cussed in Isabelo de los Reyes’ La Religion Antigua de los Fili¬ 
pinos (Manila, 1909); Fernando Blumentritt’s “Diccionarxo 
Mitologico, ” in Retana’s Archivo del Bibliofilo Filipino (Madrid, 
1896), Volume 2; and Sor Edmunde Delbeke’s Religion and 
Morals of the Early Filipinas at the Coming of the Spaniards 
(Manila, 1928). A popular work on the Muslim marriage customs 
is found in Ileana Maramag’s “Muslim Courtship and Wedding 
Customs,” The Manila Times, Section B, October 5, 1959. The 
introduction of Islam in the Philippines is discussed in Najeeb 
Saleeby’s The History of Sulu (Manila, 1908) and Studies in Moro 
History, Law, and Religion (Manila, 1905). 
CHAPTER IV 
There are several good books on Malayo-Polynesian languages, 
but the best introductory volume is Renward Brandstetter’s An In¬ 
troduction to Indonesian Linguistics (trans. C. O. Blagden, Lon¬ 
don, 1916). The Institute of National Language made a study of 
the Austronesian and Philippine languages entitled Preliminary 
Studies on the Lexicography of the Philippine Languages (Manila, 
1937), Volume I, Nos. 1-10. On the ancient Filipino syllabary 
and the system of writing, the works of Colin, Chirino, and Morga 
are indispensable. Those who would like to go into the intricacies 
of the ancient Filipino writing may consult not only Morga, 
Chirino and Colin, but also Cipriano Marcilla’s Estudio de los 
Antiguos Alfabetos Filipinos (Malabon, 1895), T. H. Pardo de 
Tavera’s Consideracidn para el Estudio de los Antiguos Alfabetos 
Filipinos (Losana, 1884), Pedro Andres de Castro’s Ortografia 
y reglas de la lengua Tagalog (Manila, 1776), and Ignacio Villa- 
mor’s La Antigua Escritura Filipina (Manila, 1922). There are 
scores of other books, from Mallat to Mas, which include samples 
of the ancient Filipino writing but most of them are superficial.

page_612.content:
592 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
On Tagalog literature, Epifanio de los Santos’ “Nuestra Li- 
teratura a traves de los siglos, ” in M.M. Norton’s Builders of a 
Nation (Manila, 1914), the same author’s Literatura Tagala (Ma¬ 
drid, 1909), and Teodoro A. Agoncillo’s “The Development of 
Tagalog Language and Literature,” Far Eastern University Faculty 
Journal, Vol. I, No. 2, October 1952, may be consulted. On the 
ancient Filipino rrasic, Epifanio de los Santos’ “Folklore Musical 
de Filipinas, ” in El Debate, November 20, 1920, and Cinco Notas 
al Capitulo Octavo de los “Sucesos de las Islas Filipinas’ del Dr. 
Antonio de Morga (Madrid, 1909) are enlightening. Also on the 
same subject, Raymundo C. Banas, The Music and Theater of the 
Filipinos (Manila, 1924) may be consulted. The author is long on 
music, but short on the drama. 
On Ilocano literature, Leopoldo Y. Yabes, A Brief Survey of 
Iloko Literature (Manila, 1936) ha4? not been improved upon. 
Nevertheless, it has not been updated. Filipino folklore is dis¬ 
cussed in Isabelo de los Reyes’ El Folklore Filipino (Manila 
1899) and in Dean S. Fansler’s Filipino Popular Tales (Lan¬ 
caster and New York, 1921). As a bibliographic guide on Philip¬ 
pine folklore, E. Arsenio Manuel’s Philippine Folklore Biblio¬ 
graphy (Quezon City, 1965) may be consulted. On the songs 
and musical instruments of the ancient Filipinos, Alfredo N. 
Munoz’s “Play a Native Melody,” The Saturday Mirror Magazine, 
February 26, 1955, F. Sionil Jose’s “Manners and Morals in 
IgoroHand,” Sunday Times Magazine, January 26, 1958, and 
Wenceslao E. Retana’s El Indio Batangueho (3rd ed., Manila, 
1888) should be consulted. A glimpse at Maranaw literature 
may be had in Abdullah T. Madale’s “The Literature of 
the Maranaws,” This Week, February 22, 1959. On Filipino 
primitive art, H. Otley Beyer’s “Filipino Art and Culture in pre- 
Spanish Times,” mimeographed, Galo B. Ocampo’s “Evolution 
of Philippine Art,” This Week, September 6, 1959 and A. V. H. 
Hartendorp’s two articles, “Ifugao Wood Carving” and “The Art 
of the Lanao Moros,” The Philippines Quarterly, September 1951 
and September 1953, respectively, are probably the best on the 
subject. 
CHAPTERS V AND VI 
For a background on Spanish colonial policy, William Ro- 
scher, The Spanish Colonial System (translated from the German 
into English, 1903; reprinted in New York, 1944), is a must. 
Sources for an enlightenment on the Renaissance period, include

page_613.content:
SELECTED REFERENCES 
593 
J. R. Hale, Renaissance Europe; Individual and Society, 1480- 
1520 (New York, 1971) and Hugh Thomas, A History of the 
World (New York, 1979). 
One should not miss reading the scholarly work on the Recon¬ 
naissance and Maritime Discovery in Boies Penrose, Travel and 
Discovery in the Renaissance, 1420-1620 (New York, 1962), 
supported by the informative* maps in Carlos A. Quirino, Philip¬ 
pine Cartography (Manila, 1959). 
For a backgrounder on Spain in the Philippines, Nicholas 
Cushner, Spain in the Philippines; From Conquest to Revolu¬ 
tion (Quezon City, 1971), gives a brief, but substantial account 
from the arrival of the Spaniards in the 16th century to the 
outbreak of the Philippine Revolution in 1896. Sources in Span¬ 
ish on the expeditions of Magellan, Loaisa, Saavedra, Villalobos 
and Legazpi, have been updated by a more modern work also 
using incontrovertible primary sources in J. Ignacio Rubio Mane, 
“La expedicion de Miguel Lopez de Legazpi a Filipinas,” appear¬ 
ing in Vol. V, nos. 3-4 (July-Dectmber, 1964) of the Boldin del 
Archivo de la Nacion (Mexico). For a quick handy guide to all 
the significant voyages of exploration, Nicholas P. Cushner, 
The Isles of the West; Early Spanis1 Voyages to the Philippines 
(Quezon City, 1966), easily describes them all in one volume. 
The Beginnings of Christianity in the Philippines (Manila, 1965), 
a compilation of selected papers read at a historical symposium 
sponsored by the Philippines Historical Committee and the Philip¬ 
pine Chapter of the International Association of Historians of 
Asia. T. V Sitoy, Jr., A History of Christianity in the Philip¬ 
pines; the Initial Encounter, 1542-1546 (Quezon City, 1985), 
Vol. I, contains several interesting new insights on the early 
Spanish voyages of discovery, as seen by a Filipino writer. 
The scholarly work on the structure of the Spanish colonial 
government is undoubtedly that of Charles H. Haring, The Spanish 
Empire in America (New York, 1963), strengthened in somt areas, 
by Onofre A. Corpuz, The Bureaucracy in the Philippines (Manila, 
1957) and Eliodoro G. Robles, The Philippines in the 19th Cen¬ 
tury (Quezon City, 1969). 
The classic work on the Manila-Acapulco trade is still William 
L. Schurz, The Manila Galleon (New York, 1959) which may 
be reinforced by studies on galleon movements in the 16th to the 
18th centuries by Pierre Chaunu Les Philippines et le Pacifique

page_614.content:
594 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
des Iberiques (Paris, 1960). The lasting cultural effects of the 
trade are discussed excellently in Silvio Zavala, El mundo ameri- 
cano en la epoca colonial (2 v., Mexico, 1967) and Rafael Bernal, 
Prologue to Philippine History (Manila, 1967). 
The scholarly treatise on the Royal Philippine Company 
remains Maria Lourdes Diaz-Trechuelo, La Real Compahia de Fi- 
lipinas (Seville, 1965) which recounts the rise and fall of the 
company from 1785 to 1834, although James F. Cloghessy, 
“The Philippines and the Royal Philippine Company,” Mid-Ame¬ 
rica 42 (1960), pp. 88-104, is also useful. However, one should 
not miss the series of five articles prepared by Maria Lourdes 
Diaz-Trechuelo on 18th century Philippine economy, which 
appeared in the Philippine Studies, from April, 1963 to April, 
1966, on various aspects: economic development plans, mining, 
agriculture, and commerce. 
Eighteenth century economy in the Philippines is lengthily 
discussed in the award-winning dissertation of Jose Cosano Moyano, 
Filipinas y su real hacienda, 1750-1800 (Cordoba, 1986), treating 
on financing in the Philippines in the second half of the 18th 
century, fiscal structure (1750-1774), sale of offices and Filipino 
tributes. This work clarifies some of the “gray areas” in Carl C. 
Plehn, ‘ Taxation in the Philippines,” Political Science Quarterly 
(1902), pp. 644-689, also republished in the Journal of History 
10/2 (June 1962), pp. 135-92. Leoncio Gonzales Liquete’s 
delightfully informative, almost unused articles on Philippine 
economic history by Filipino and foreign historians are found in 
his Repertorio historico, biografico y bibliografico; colleccion 
de obras publicadas hasta el presente en la prensa de Manila 
(3 v., Manila, 1930). Two brief analytical works on Philippine 
economy during the Spanish regime, undoubtedly, are Benito 
Legarda, Jr.’s “The Philippine Economy under Spanish Rule,” 
Solidarity 11/10 (November-December, 1967), and Horacio de la 
Costa’s “Nineteenth Century” in Progress (1957) and “Philippine 
Economic Development” in his Asia and the Philippines (Manila, 
1967). The almost unknown Salem-Manila trade is discussed 
in Nathaniel Bowditch, Early American-Philippine Trade, 1796 
(New Haven, Conn., 1962), supported by Isagani R. Medina, 
“American Logbooks and Journals in Salem, Massachusetts on 
the Philippines, 1796-1894,” Asian Studies (April, 1973). 
Works on the vicissitudes of the Filipino clergy should start 
with Horacio de la Costa, “The Development of the Native Clergy

page_615.content:
SELECTED REFERENCES 
595 
in the Philippines,” in Gerald H. Anderson, (ed.), Studies in 
Philippine Church History (Ithaca, 1969) and pertinent portions, 
in John Schumacher, Readings in Philippine Church History 
(Quezon City, 1979). The Filipino-centric view which rectifies 
some earlier findings of De la Costa and Schumacher on the early 
Filipino priests, are presented in Luciano P. R. Santiago, The 
Hidden Light: the First Filipino Priests (Quezon City, 1987). 
The persistent irritating problems of haciendas are fully 
discussed in Dennis M. Roth, The Friar Estate of the Philippines 
(Albuquerque, New Mexico, 1977) and Nicholas Cushner, Landed 
Estates in the Colonial Philippines (New Haven, 1976). 
The Cavite Mutiny of 1872 can best be understood by reading 
Leandro Tormo Sanz’s two works: 1872; Documents Compiled 
and Annotated (Manila, 1973) and “La huelga del Arsenal de 
Cavite en 1872,” (Seville, 1978). 
The Filipino-centric view on the survey of education during 
the Spanish regime is discussed in the classic work of Encamacion 
Alzona, A History of Education in the Philippines, 1565-1930 
(Manila, 1932); Dalmacio Martin, (ed.) “A Century of Education 
in the Philippines, 1861-1961,” (Manila, 1980), and Domingo 
Abella, “State of Higher Education in the Philppines to 1863; 
a Historical Reappraisal,” Philippine Historical Review 1/1 (1965), 
pp. 1-46. Jose Rizal, “The Town Schools in the Philippines,” 
in his Miscellaneous Writings (Manila, 1964), gives a perspective 
never found in other works of the same nature. 
New views on whether the Filipinos were totally Hispanized 
or not are presented in Samuel K. Tan, A History of the Philip¬ 
pines (Quezon City, 1987) and Vicente L. Rafael, Contracting 
Colonialism; Translation and Christian Conversion in Tagalog 
Society under Early Spanish Rule (Quezon City, 1988). 
CHAPTER VII 
, N \ . % % • -X 
Research in sporadic pocket revolts the Spanish era, especially 
in the* 19th century, are still virtually untouched by most students 
of Philippine history. The records are found in the National 
Archives of the Philippines, Spanish Records Section in the 
record group labeled Sediciones y rebeliones. 
The “Conspiracy of the maharlikas of 1587-88” is lengthily 
treated in the “Conspiracy against the Spaniards, May-July,

page_616.content:
596 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
1589,” in Blair and Robertson, vol. 7, pp. 95-111. The “In¬ 
surrections by Filipinos in the Seventeenth Century” that is, 
from the armed resistance of the Gaddangs (1621) to the Zam- 
bals (1683), are found in vol. 38, pp. 87-240, of Blair and Ro- 
berston, culled from various accounts written by early Spanish 
friar chroniclers. Sumodoy’s revolt is best described in Ignacio 
Alzina, “Description of the Towns of Sulat, Tubig, Bobon and 
Catarman and of the Palapag Uprising in 1649,” Philippiniana 
Sacm 17/49 (January-April, 1982), pp. 123-85; 17/50 (May- 
August, 1982), p. 106. Of course, one should not miss Cantius 
J. Kobak, “Historical Survey of Palapag, Samar, and the Sumoroy 
Rebellion of 1649,” Ley te-Samar Studies 2/1 (1968), pp. 44-91. 
Augmenting the religious chroniclers on Filipino revolts are the 
secular historians like Jose Montero y Vidal Historia general de 
Filipinas (3 v., Madrid, 1887-1895), and by contemporary writers, 
Felix H. Keesing, The Ethnohistory of Northern Luzon (Stanford, 
1962) for the armed uprisings in the Cordilleras and Cesar Majul, 
Muslims in the Philippines (Quezon City, 1973) and Samuel K. 
Tan, “Sulu under American Military Rule, 1899-1913,” Phil¬ 
ippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review 32/1 (March, 
1967), pp. 6-20, ior the protracted “Moro Wars.” 
The not so well-known revolts of Magtangaga, Caragay, and 
Rivera are described in Fathers Domingo Collantes, Historia de 
la provincia del Sanusimo Rosario de Filipinas (Manila 1783), 
Julian Malumbres, Historia de Cagayan and Historia de Isabela 
(Manila, 1918), and of course, corroborated and supplemented 
by Juan Ferrando, Historia de los pp. Dominicos en las Islas 
Filipinas (6 v., Madrid, 1870-72). Palaris’ revolt is best described 
in Jose S. Arcilla, “The Pangasinan Uprising, 1762-1765,” Philip¬ 
pine Historical Review IV (1971), pp. 32-52. For sources on 
Silang’s revolt, the Augustinian Fr. Pedro de Vivar s ocular ac¬ 
count, “Relation de los alzamientos de la ciudad de Vigan, cabe- 
cera de la Provincia de Ilocos, en los ahos de 1762 y 1763,” 
in Biblioteca Hisiorica Filipina (Manila, 1893), vol 4, pp. 283- 
4r<8, ranks the best, supplemented by Manilha Consultations, 
1762-1764; Records of Fort St. George 8 v., Madras, 1940-46), 
particularly vol. 7. 
Archival sources on “Ermano Apolinaiio de la Cruz’” revolt 
a^e found at the National Archives of the Philippines in Manila, 
which can be augmented by David Sturtevant, Popular Uprisings 
in the Philippines, 1840-1940 (Ithaca, 1976) and Leandro Tormo 
Sanz, “La reaparicion de la Cofradia de San Jose de Tayabas, ” in 
Anuario de Esiudios Americanos 32 (1975), pp. 485-507.

page_617.content:
SELECTED REFERENCES 
597 
For the peasant revolt in Silang, Cavite, led by Joseph de la 
Vega in 1745, the “Diligencias fhas. sobre la revelion (sic) tumul- 
tuaria de los yndios del pueblo de Silan y de otros,” dated April 
28, 1745, found at the Archivo General de Indias in Seville, Spain 
(AGI, Filipinos, 288), and the copies of documents at the Do¬ 
minican archives in San Juan, Metro Manila, are the principal 
primary sources as “The Revolt of 1745,” found in Roth, The 
Friar Estates (1977), pp. 100-16 and Artigas, Historia de Fili¬ 
pinos (1912). The Luis Parang and Juan Up ay’s agrarian up¬ 
rising in Cavite in 1822 and the Eduardo Camerino — led revolt 
in the mid-1860s, are discussed in Isagani R. Medina, “La madre 
de los ladrones; tulisanismo in Cavite in the Nineteenth Century,” 
Philippine Social Sciences Review (January-December, 1984), 
pp. 215-289. 
Irene Collins, “Liberalism in Nineteenth-Century Europe,” 
in E. C. Black, European History, 1815-1870 (New York, 1967) 
is a “must” reading. Carlos Maria de la Torre and his alleged 
liberal policy which culminated later in the Cavite Mutiny of 
1872, can be best understood, if one reads his Manifiesto al pais 
sobre los sucesos de Cavite (Madrid, 1872); Manuel Artigas y 
Cuerva, Los sucesos de 1872 (Manila, 1911); Edmond Plauchut, 
“The Cavite Uprising of 1872,” Philippine Historical Bulletin 
IV/4 (December, 1960), pp. 1-16, which is the English translation 
of his La algarada caviteha de 1872 (Manila, 1916) originally 
published in French; and John N. Schumacher and Nicholas P. 
Cushner, (ed.), “Documents Relating to Father Jose Burgos and 
the Cavite Mutiny of 1872,” Philippine Studies 17/3 (July, 1969), 
pp. 457-529, among other works. 
CHAPTER VIII 
Readings for this chapter are numerous, some of which are 
either not available or are difficult to come by. Only the most 
important are indicated here. For Rizal’s life, Rafael Palma’s 
Biografia de Rizal (English translation The Pride of the Malay 
Race by Roman Ozaeta) and Leon Ma. Guerrero, Jr.’s The First 
Filipino (Manila, 1963) are the best. For a short biography of 
Lopez Jaena, the best are Mariano Ponce’s “Graciano Lopez 
Jaena”, in Efemerides Filipinos (Manila, 1914), and Jaime C. De 
Veyra’s “Graciano Lopez Jaena: Estudio Biogrdfico ”, in the re¬ 
issue of Discursos y articulos various (Manila, 1951). Anecdotes 
about Lopez Jaena are found in Jose Alejandrino’s The Price of 
Freedom (Manila, 1949). On the life of Marcelo H. del Pilar,

598 
HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
the following may be consulted: Epifanio de los Santos, “Mar- 
celo H. del Pilar,’ Revista Filipina, June 1920; and Teodoro A. 
Agoncillo, “Marcelo H. del Pilar: A Challenge and a Symbol,” 
Philippine Review, August 1944, and Magno Gatmaitan, Marcelo 
H. del pi/ar. 1850-1896 (Quezon City, Munoz Press, 1966). Del 
Pilar’s pamphlets are difficult to come by, but some of them are 
reprinted in E. de los Santos’ essay mentioned above. Copies of 
La Solidaridad are now very rare, but a discussion of the period¬ 
ical is found in Jesus Z. Valenzuela’s History of Journalism in the 
Philippine Islands (Manila, 1933) and in Mariano Ponce’s ‘La 
Solidaridad”, in Efemirides Filipinas. 
For Masonry and its role, Teodoro M. Kalaw’s La Masoneria 
Filipinas (Manila, 1920) is the best. This work was translated 
into English and published in 1955 under the title Philippine 
Masonry. Teodoro A. Agoncillo’s The Revolt of the Masses: 
The Story of Bonifacio and the Katipunan (Quezon City, 1956) 
was used heavily in this chapter. 
CHAPTER IX 
This chapter is to a large extent a resume of several chapters 
of Agoncillo’s The Revolt of the Masses . . . .For important refer¬ 
ences, see bibliography of this book. 
CHAPTER X 
The substance of this chapter has been culled from Agoncillo’s 
Revolt of the Masses . . . and from l^lalolos: The Crisis of the 
Republic (Quezon City, 1960). On some documents concerning 
the Katipunan and its discovery, W. E. Retana’s Archivo del 
Bibliofilo Filipino (Madrid, 1891), Volume 3, is probably the best. 
Care, however, should be taken in reading the testimonies of the 
witnesses, for they had been taken at the point of the bayonet. 
On the battles fought, Manuel Sastron's La InsurrecciSn en Fili¬ 
pinas (Madrid, 1897), Vol I, represents the Spanish viewpoint. 
Most of Sastron’s data were taken from newspaper reports gather¬ 
ed and published by R. Guerrero under the title Cronica de la 
Guerra de Cuba y de la Rebelion de Filipinas (Barcelona, 1896- 
1897), in five volumes. Volumes 4 and 5 deal with the revolu¬ 
tion in the Philippines. A first-hand information on the Revolu¬ 
tion (1896-1898) is found in Carlos Ronquillo’s Paghihimagsik 
nang 1896-97, still in manuscript form.

SELECTED REFERENCES 
599 
The documents on the trial of Bonifacio and others accused of 
sedition and treason are in the Philippine Insurgent Records, but 
an English translation is found in Teodoro A. Agoncillo’s’ 77ie 
Writings and Trial of Andres Bonifacio (Manila, 1963). On the 
Truce of Biyak-na-bato, the best are Pedro A. Patemo’s El Pacto 
de Biyak-na-bato (Manila, 1910) and Fernando Primo de Rivera’s 
Memoria dirigida al Senado^(Madrid, 1898). The documents 
on the Truce are found in the Philippine Insurgent Records. 
The events leading to the Truce and its final outcome are dis¬ 
cussed in Agoncillo’s Malolos: The Crisis of the Republic. For the 
Filipino viewpoint, General Aguinaldo’s Reseha Veridica de la 
Revolucion Filipina (Tarlak, 1899) should be read. 
CHAPTER XI 
The contents of this chapter have been culled from Agoncillo’s 
Malolos: The Crisis of the Republic. Most of the sources are doc¬ 
umentary and are found in the Philippine Insurgent Records. For 
Aguinaldo’s version of his conferences with Pratt, Wildman, and 
Dewey, see his Reseha Veridica . . . For the American viewpoints, 
see Dewey’s Autobiography (New York, 1913) and Pratt’s and 
Wildman’s letters to the State Department in Senate Document 
No. 62, Part I, 55th Congress, 3rd. Session. For eyewitness 
accounts of the battle of Manila, August 13, 1898, see F. D. 
Millet’s The Expedition to the Philippines (New York, 1899), 
Jesse George’s Our Army and Navy in the Orient (Manila, 1899), 
and the articles included in Marion Wilcox’s Harper’s History of 
the War in the Philippines (New York and London, 1900). 
CHAPTERS XII AND XIII 
The substance of these chapters has been culled from Agon¬ 
cillo’s Malolos: The Crisis of the Republic, the documentary sources 
of which are found in the Philippine Insurgent Records. On the 
American version of the Filipino-American hostilities, the best 
sources are the various Reports of the Major-General Command¬ 
ing the Army (Washington, 1899-1902). Care, however* should 
be taken in reading these reports, particularly with reference to 
the battles fought, for many of the reports had been tailored to 
suit the authorities in Washington. Wilcox’s Harper’s History of 
the War . , . contains valuable information on the different phases 
of the conflict. So far, no extensive Filipino account of the armed 
conflict has been written and published. General Venancio 
Concepcion’s diaries, Apuntes y Diario de Operaciones, are no

page_620.content:
600 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
« 
longer available and only parts of the whole were available to a 
few scholars before the last war. Other sources, mainly American, 
are the following: Karl Irving Faust’s Campaigning in the Philip¬ 
pines (San Francisco, 1899, Albert G. Robinson’s The Philip¬ 
pines, the War and the People (New York, 1901), Frederick 
Funston’s Memories of Two Wars (New York, 1911), and Senate 
Document No. 331, three volumes (Washington, 1902). 
CHAPTER XIV 
The sources for the writing of the Aglipayan Movement are 
abundant, but most of them are not readily available. Those easily 
available are Juan A. Rivera’s “The Aglipayan Movement,” The 
Philippine Social Science Review, Vol. 9, No. 4, December 1937, 
and Francis H. Wise’s The History of the Philippine Independent 
Church (Master’s Thesis, University of the Philippines, 1954). 
Some of the documents which deal with the Filipino national 
church and the second phase of the Revolution are found in the 
Philippine Insurgent Records. A few of these documents are 
included in Teodoro M. Kalaw’s edition of Mabini’s La Revo- 
lucion Filipina con otros documentos de la epoca (Manila, 1931), 
volume 2. For the biographies of Aglipay and Isabelo de los 
Reyes, see Manuel Artigas y Cuerva’s Galeria de Filipinos Ilustres 
(Manila, 1917), Volume I, and Jose L. Llanes’ “Life and Labors 
of Isabelo de los Reyes,” The Diliman Review, U.P. Golden 
Jubilee Number, April-December 1958. Pedro S. de Achutegui, 
and Miguel A. Bernad’s, both Jesuits, Religious Revolution in the 
Philippines (Manila, 1960), Vol. I, may be consulted with caution. 
Another biography by a Spanish Augustinian is Isacio Rodriguez’s 
Gregorio Aglipay y los Origines de la Iglesia Filipina Independiente 
(1898-1917), Madrid, 1960), Naturally, it is pro-Spanish. Another 
biography of Isabelo de los Reyes is found in Jose de los Reyes* 
Biography of Senator Isabelo de los Reyes . . . (Manila, 1947). 
The religious question is ably presented in the second volume 
of James A. LeRoy’s The Americans in the Philippines (Boston 
and New York, 1914). The documents relating to the early 
Aglipayan Movement were published in the periodical edited by 
I. de los Reyes, La Iglesia Filipina Independiente, 1903-1904. 
Some of the historical aspects of Aglipayanism are found in Manuel 
Lagasca’s Iglesia Filipina Independiente: Su origen, significacion e 
importancia (Manila, 1939).

CHAPTER XV 
For further information or details on the Filipino continuing 
resistance, the following sources may be useful: the reports of 
local events published in several of the newspapers and tabloids 
especially in the microfilm copies of The Manila Times; James 
H. Blount’s The American Occupation of the Philippinesy 1898- 
1912 which is an eyewitness- account of an American judge who 
actually implemented some of the policies against Filipino in¬ 
surgents in the colony; the Annual Reports of the Philippine 
Commission, 1900-1915, during which time the Commission per¬ 
formed the functions of the executive and legislative branches of 
the government and recorded the state of the colony and its 
problems; Theodore Friend’s Between Two Empires (Quezon 
City, 1969) which is a clear analysis of general relations between 
two allies turned enemies in the first decade and subsequently 
had to cope with problems of resolving their conflict of interests; 
Bonifacio Salamanca’s Filipino Reaction to American Ruley 
1901-1913 Norwich, Conn, USA, 1968 which is a Filipino’s 
contemporary assessment of a controversial and bloddy decade 
of American colonial rule. * 
For understanding of and insight into the non-Christian 
resistance up to 1913, the following sources may be consulted: 
Peter Gowing’s Mandate Over Moroland (PCAS, UP, 1977) which 
has a lot of details on the various uprisings in the Muslim areas, 
especially in Lanao; Samuel K. Tan’s Sulu Under American Mili¬ 
tary Rule, 1899-1913 (UP, 1967) which analyzes the cause of 
several Tausug armed disturbance against American rule despite 
the Bates Treaty, and The Filipino Muslim Armed Struggle (Maka¬ 
ti, 1978) which deals in the earlier chapters with the various 
patterns of disturbances in the Muslim areas; Howard Fry’s A 
History of the Mountain Province (Quezon City, 1985) which 
provides detailed description of American rule in the Cordillera 
and is a good complement to Henry Scott’s Discovery of the 
Igorots which deals with the Spanish period; Frank Jenista’s 
The White Apos (Quezon City, 1987) which is an interesting 
description and analysis of American rule under certain Amer¬ 
ican officers or officials; and Victor Hurley’s The Swish of the 
Kris (New York, 1936) which gives primary insight into Amer¬ 
ican problems with Sulu Muslims during the first decade. 
CHAPTER XVI 
The other side of American military rule, which was marked 
by Filipino compromise and cooperation, is treated in both

page_622.content:
602 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
American and Filipino sources. The following may be useful 
for insight into the non-revolutionary type of Filipino reaction: 
George Taylor’s The United States and the Philippines: Problems 
of Partnership (Praeger, 1964) which presents the mutuality of 
interests and benefits American rule brought to the colony in a 
historical perspective; J. Moorefield Storey and Marcial P. Lichau- 
co’s The Conquest of the Philippines by the United States, 1898- 
1925 (New York, 1926) which is a primary analysis of the first 
decade of American rule showing the American design to create a 
favorable Filipino attitude to American colonial rule; W. Cameron 
Forbes, The Philippine Islands (Boston, 1928), which is a rich 
source of primary data on American policies, programs, and views 
of Filipino leadership as it related to American officialdom by 
an author who served the colony as Governor General during the 
last years of the first decade; and The Mindanao Journal, Vol. 
VIII, Nos. 1-4, which is collection of contemporary articles on 
various aspects of American rule in Mindanao showing the pattern 
of American non-military penetration of Southern Philippines 
during the first two decades. Other useful references include 
Francis Burton Harrison, The Cornerstone of Philippine Inde¬ 
pendence (New York, 1922). Onofre D. Corpuz, The Bureau¬ 
cracy in the Philippine (Manila, 1957); and Peter W. Stanley, 
A Nation in the Making; The Philippines and the United States, 
1899-1921 (Cambridge, 1974). 
The American successful pacification of the Cordillera region 
is well covered in Howard Fry’s A History of Mountain Province 
(Quezon City, 1985) beginning from Chapter 3 on the creation 
of the province to Chapter 6 which discusses the period of transi¬ 
tion to Filipino rule during the Harrison administration. In these 
chapters the integration of the Cordillera local leadership was 
obvious. 
CHAPTER XVII 
The following are useful sources for the Wood Administration, 
and particularly for the “Crisis” which developed between Wood 
and the Filipino leaders: Michael Onorato, A Brief Review of 
American Interest in Philippine Development and Other Essays 
(Berkeley, 1968); Jorge C. Bocobo, General Wood and the Law: 
A Discussion of the Legal Aspects of the Political Crisis in the 
Philippine Islands (Manila, 1924); Hermann Hagedorn, Leonard 
Wood: A Biography (New York, 1931); Ronald F. Chapman, 
Leonard Wood and Leprosy in the Philippines: The Culion Leper

603 
Colony, 1921-1927 (Lanham, Md., 1982); and Bemardita Reyes 
Churchill, The Philippine Independence Missions to the United 
States, 1919-1934 (Manila, 1983). Documentary and official 
sources may be found in the Annual Reports of the Governor 
General, 1922-1926 (Washington, 1922-1927). 
On Henry L. Stimson, the following are informative: Henry 
L. Stimson and McGeorge Bundy, On Active Service in War and 
Peace (New York, 1947); and Elting Morrison, Turmoil and 
Tradition: The Life and Times of Henry L. Stimson (Boston, 
1960). See also the following: Katherine Mayo, The Isles of 
Fear: The Truth About the Philippines (New York, 1924); Moor- 
field Storey and Marcial P. Lichauco, The Conquest of the Philip¬ 
pines by the United States, 1898-1925 (New York, 1926), Theo¬ 
dore Roosevelt, Jr., Colonial Policies of the United States (New 
York, 1937); Lewis Gleeck, Jr., The American Governors-General 
and High Commissioners in the Philippines (Quezon City, 1986). 
For literature on Quezon and Osmena, see the following 
sources: Manuel L. Quezon, The Good Fight (New York, 1946); 
Carlos Quirino, Quezon: Paladin of Philippine Freedom (Manila, 
1971); Teodoro M. Kalaw, Aide-de-Camp to Freedom (Manila, 
1965); John Gunther, Inside Asia (New York, 1942); Vicente 
Albano Pacis, President Sergio Osmena: A Fully Documented 
Biography (Quezon City, 1971). 
For an account of the development of political parties in the 
Philippines, see Dapen Liang, The Development of Philippine 
Political Parties (Hongkong, 1939); revised as Philippine Parties 
and Politics (San Francisco, 1970). 
CHAPTER XVIII 
The materials for the campaign for independence include the 
following: J. Ralston Hayden, The Philippines, A Study in Nation¬ 
al Development (New York, 1945); Bemardita Reyes Churchill, 
The Philippine Independence Missions to the United States, 
1919rl934 (Manila, 1983); Theodore Friend, Between Two 
Empires: The Ordeal of the Philippines (New Haven, 1965) and 
his following articles: “American Interests and Philippine In¬ 
dependence, 1929-1933,” Philippine Studies (October 1963); 
“Philippine Interests and the Mission for Independence, 1929- 
1932,” Philippine Studies (January 1964); “Philippine Independ¬ 
ence and the Last Lame-Duck Congress,” Philippine Studies

(April 1964); and “The Philippine Sugar Industry and the Politics 
of Independence, 1929-1935; “Journal of Asian Studies, 22 
(1963); Teodoro M. Kalaw, Aide-de-Camp to Freedom (Manila, 
1965). L 
On the drafting of the Commonwealth Constitution, see The 
Proceedings of the Constitutional Convention, 1934-1935 (Manila, 
1967); Jose M. Aruego, The Framing of the Philippine Consti¬ 
tution (Manila, 1936); and Miguel Cuademo, The Framing of the 
Constitution of the Philippines (Manila, 1937). 
For a discussion of the forces which contributed towards the 
settling of the Philippine independence issue, see the following: 
Grayson V. Kirk, Philippine Independence - Motives, Problems 
and Prospects (New York, 1936): Bruno Lasker, Filipino Immigra¬ 
tion to the Continental United States and Hawaii (Chicago, 1931); 
Josefa M. Same!,* (ed.); The Filipino Exclusion Movement, 1927- 
1935 (Quezon City, 1967).

CHAPTER XIX 
There is no definitive and authoritative history of the Com¬ 
monwealth, but there are some very interesting and useful works 
available. 
J. Ralston Hayden’s The Philippines, A Study in National 
Development and Theodore Friend’s Between Two Empires 
discuss aspects of the Commonwealth period. A more recent 
work is Aruna Gopinath, “The Philippines, 1935-1941: A His¬ 
torical Study in Quezonian Leadership,” Ph.D., history, Uni¬ 
versity of the Philippines, 1984. See also Carol Morris Petillo, 
Douglas MacArthur: The Philippine Years (Bloomington, Ind., 
1981); Sidney Fine, Frank Murphy: The New Deal Years, vol. II, 
The Philippine Years, pp. 38-202 (Chicago, 1979); Francis Burton 
Harrison, Origins of the Philippine Republic, edited and annotated 
by Michael P. Onorato (Itahaca, NY, 1974); Florence Horn, Orphans 
of the Pacific: The Philippines (New York, 1941); RoyamaMasa- 
michi and Takeuchi Tatsuji, The Philippine Polity: A Japanese 
View (New Haven, 1967); and Alfred W. McCoy’s chapter in 
Philippine Colonial Democracy, edited by Ruby Paredes (New 
Haven, 1989). 
On the economic development of the period and the problems 
which faced the Commonwealth, see the following: Amado A.

Castro, “The Philippines: A Study in Economic Dependence,” 
Ph.D., Harvard University, 1954; Norman Owen, “Philippine 
Economic Development and American Policy: A Reappraisal,” in 
Compadre Colonialism (Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1971); Pedro E. Abe- 
larde, American Tariff Policy Toward the Philippines, 1898-1946 
(New York, 1947). For a discussion of the “Japanese problem,” See 
Grant K. Goodman, Davao: A Case Study in Japanese-Philippine 
Relations (Kansas, 1967); Soledad M. Borromeo, “The Japanese 
and the Davao Land Question,” M.A., UP, 1965; Milagros C. 
Guerrero, A Survey of Japanese Trade and Investments in the 
Philippines, 1900-1941 (Quezon City, 1969). See also A.V.H. 
Hartendorp, History of Industry and Trade of the Philippines 
(Manila, 1958); David R. Sturtevant, Popular Uprisings in the 
Philippines, 1840-1940 (Ithaca, NY, 1376). 
For published official sources, see the following: Report of 
the Special Mission to the United States, 1938-1939 (Manila, 
1939); United States Tariff Commission's Report on United 
States-Philivpine Trade, with Special Reference to the Philip¬ 
pine Independence Act and Other Recent Legislation (Washing¬ 
ton, 1939); Summary of the Report, American-Philippine Trade 
Relations by the Technical Committee to the President (1944); 
Report of the Joint Preparatory Committee on Philippine Affairs, 
May 20, 1938; Report on National Defense in the Philippines 
(Manila, 1936). 
CHAPTER XX 
Philippine progress in education under the Americans is dis¬ 
cussed in Encamacion Alzona’s A History of Education in the 
Philippines (Manila, 1932), W. Cameron Forbes’ The Philippine 
Islands (Boston and New York, 1928), Volume 1, and J. Ralston 
Hayden1 s The Philippines: A Study In National Development. 
Other aspects of the American occupation are also found in the 
last two books mentioned above and in Garel A. Grunder and 
■ 
William E. Livezey’s The Philippines and the United States. 
Philippine progress in industry and trade is discussed in A. V. H. 
Hartendorp’s History of Industry and Trade of the Philippines 
(Manila, 1958). Health improvement is discussed in Forbes and 
Hayden and in Victor Heiser’s An American Doctor's Odyssey 
(New York, 1936). The Philippine Census of 1903 and 1918 
are important sources of information on social, educational, and 
economic aspects. The best guide on Filipino literature in English 
is Leopoldo Y. Yabes’ Philippine Literature, 1898-1957: A Biblio-

graphical Survey (Quezon City, 1958). The American influence 
on the national language is discussed in Teodoro A. Agoncillo’s 
“The Development of the Tagalog Language and Literature” 
and in his draft of a work on the American influence on the 
Tagalog literature and language. 
CHAPTER XXI 
There is a plethora of original sources on the Japanese occu¬ 
pation; only the most salient, however, are indicated here. The 
best sources are easily the occupation Tribune and the Official 
Journal of the Japanese Military Administration Manila, 1942- 
1943), 13 volumes. Theodore Roosevelt’s role in the Philippine 
independence program is found in Henry F. Pringle’s Theodore 
Roosevelt (Harvest Books, New York, 1956); General Douglas 
Mac-Arthur’s role is found in Francis Trevelyan Miller’s General 
MacArthur (Philadelphia, 1945) and in Douglas MacArthur’s 
Reminiscences (New York, 1964). The series of events leading to 
the war is found in the newspaper accounts, principally in the 
Manila Tribune and the Manila Daily Bulletin, 1940-1941. The 
military side is ably presented in Louis Morton’s The Fall of the 
Philippines (Washington, 1953). Manuel L. Quezon’s The Good 
Fight (New York and London, 1946) presents the Filipino view¬ 
point of the war. Critical accounts of the occupation years are 
found in Hernando Abaya’s Betrayal in the Philippines (New 
York, 1946) and Eliseo Quirino’s A Day to Remember (Manila, 
1958). A defense of the role of some Filipino officials during 
the occupation is masterfully presented in Claro M. Recto’s 
Three Years of Enemy Occupation: The Issue of Political Colla¬ 
boration in the Philippines (Manila, 1946). The senior author has 
written a two-volume work, The Fateful Years: Japan’s Adventure 
in the Philippines, 1941-1945 (Quezon City, 1965), Jorge B. 
Vargas’ role during the occupation is presented in Armando J. 
Malay’s Occupied Philippines (Manila, Filipiniana Book Guild, 
1967). 
CHAPTER XXII 
There are several good accounts of the guerrilla warfare in 
the Philippines, each recording the events in a particular place or 
area. The story of the guerrillas of northern Luzon is told in 
Guerrilla Days in North Luzon (Manila, 1946) and R. W. Volck- 
mann’s We Remained (New York, 1954). Some guerrilla activities 
are also recorded in M. Hamlin Cannon’s Leyte: The Return to the

page_627.content:
SELECTED REFERENCES 
607 
Philippines (Washington, 1954). Other books, dealing with 
guerrilla activities “are Yay Marking’s The Crucible (New York, 
1950); Ira Wolfert’s American Guerrilla in the Philippines (New 
York, 1945); Edward Haggerty’s Guerrilla Padre in Mindanao 
(New York and Toronto, 1946); Forbes J. Monaghan’s Under the 
Red Sun (New York, 1946); Joseph F. St. John’s Leyte Calling 
(New York, 1945); and Jose D. Doromal’s The War in Panay 
(Manila, 1952). The odyssey of the govemment-in-exile is found 
in Quezon’s The Good Flight. 
The accounts of the naval battles leading to the liberation of 
the Philippines are found in several good official and eyewitness 
reports: Admiral Frederick C. Sherman’s “The Battles of the Phil¬ 
ippine Sea/1 The Manila Times, July 14 to August 5, 1947; Fleet 
Admiral Ernest J. King’s Second Official Report Covering Combat 
Operations March 1, 1945, a separate pamphlet issued by the 
United States News; and Lt. Oliver Jensen’s Carrier War (New 
York, 1945). A rather highly technical account of the naval and 
land battles is found in H. Hamlin Cannon’s Leyte: The Return to 
the Philippines. Better and certainly more readable works on the 
subject are Samuel Eliot Morison’s Leyte: June 1944 — January 
1945 (Boston, 1958) and The Liberation of the Philippines, 1944- 
1945 (Boston, 1959), and MacArthur’s Reminiscences. For some 
documents on Japan’s blueprint for the conquest of Southeast 
Asia, see Harry J. Benda, et. al., Japanese Military Administration 
in Indonesia (Yale University, 1965). The Japanese version of the 
battle for Leyte Gulf is found in James A. Field, Jr.’s The Japan¬ 
ese At Leyte Gulf: The Sho Operation (New Haven, 1947). 
The American Army’s Free Philippines, both the Leyte-Samar 
and the Manila editions, published daily from October 29,1944 to 
September 3, 1945, is an important source of information on the 
events in the Philippines and the world at large during the period. 
CHAPTER XXIII 
The data for this chapter have been taken for the most part 
from«the files of The Manila Chronicle, The Manila Times, and The 
Manila Post, 1945-1948. The inside stories of the important events 
of 1945-1946 have been based on the senior author’s diaries and 
on Hernando Abaya’s Betrayal in the Philippines. Agreements 
entered into by the Philippines with foreign countries are found in 
the Department of Foreign Affairs’ Treaty Series, 1947 on Roxas’ 
speeches and important pronouncements have been collected into

HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE 
Important Speeches, Messages, and Other Pronouncements of 
President Manuel Roxas (Manila, 1947). 
CHAPTER XXIV 
The literature on the Hukbalahap Movement is vast and for¬ 
midable. Being contemporary history, most of the data have been 
taken from the files of The Manila Chronicle, The Manila Times, 
and the Daily Mirror, 1945-1954, inclusive. An authoritative ac¬ 
count of the Huk movement is found in Luis M. Taruc’s Born of 
the People (New York, 1953). The files of Camp Crame are rich 
in Huk lore. The senior author used them in writing this chapter. 
A brief account of the communist movement in the Philippines is 
found in Jose M. Crisol’s The Red Lie (Manila, 1954), Appendix 
A. Less biased and more informed accounts than Crisol’s are 
Alfredo B. Saulo’s Communism in the Philippines: An Introduc¬ 
tion (Quezon City, Ateneo de Manila University, 1969) and 
Ildefcnso T. Runes’c “The Red Chapter,” in The Manila Chro¬ 
nicle, February 13-19, 1967. The official account of the peasant 
movement is found in an anonymous document, The Peasant 
War in the Philippines, originally issued in mimeographed foim in 
1946 and reprinted as a document in the Philippine Social Sciences 
and Humanities Review, Volume 23, Nos. 2-4, June-December 
1958, and in another anonymous document, History of the 
Peasant and Labor Movement in the Philippines, found in the 
Camp Crame files. 
A brief survey of the agrarian unrest in the Philippines is found 
in J. Ralston Hayden’s The Philippines: A Study in National Dev¬ 
elopment. The history of the socialist movement is traced in 
Quirino Abad Santos’ “The Historical Background of the Huk 
Movement,” Philippine Journal of Education, Volume 32, No. 9 
March 1954. A sociological view of the agrarian problem is found 
in Alvin H. Scaff’s The Philippine Answer to Communism (Stan 
ford, 1955). Hernando Abaya’s Betrayal in the Philippines con¬ 
tains inside stories about Taruc and Roxas. 
CHAPTER XXV 
Most of the data for this chapter have been taken from the 
files of the dailies, particularly The Manila Times, The Manila 
Chronicle, and the Daily Mirror, 1952-1959. Official documents 
include the State of-the-Nation Addresses of Magsaysay and 
Garcia, 1954-1958. The role of the American Central Intelligence

page_629.content:
SELECTED REFERENCES 
609 
Agency in the election of Magsaysay is found in David Wise and 
Thomas B. Ross’s The Invisible Government (Bantam Book, 
1964). 
CHAPTER XXVI 
The sources for this chapter are mainly the dailies and week¬ 
lies, particularly The Manila. Times, The Manila Chronicle, The 
Philippines Free Press, and Graphic. The officially published 
State-of-the-Nation Addresses of Macapagal and Marcos have also 
been consulted and used. 
CHAPTER XXVII 
The data for this chapter have been drawn largely from the 
dailies and the publications of the Central Bank, the Department 
of Commerce and Industry, and the National Economic Council. 
More particularly, the Central Bank’s Economic Indicators and the 
Department of Commerce and Industry’s annual publication, 
Philippine Industry and Trade, are a great help in reviewing the 
country’s economy. The policies of the Presidents of the Philip¬ 
pines are found in Manuel Roxas’ The Problems of Philippine 
Rehabilitation and Trade Relations (Manila, 1947), Elpidio 
Quirino’s The New Philippine Ideology (Manila, 1949), Ramon 
Magsaysay’s State-of-therNation Address for 1954, 1955, 1956, 
and 1957, and Carlos P. Garcia’s State-of-the-Nation Address 
for 1958 and 1959. 
Laws dealing with nationalization are found in Handbook of 
Philippine Nationalization Laws (Revised ed., Manila, 1956). The 
section on labor is taken partly from The Philippines: A Hand¬ 
book of Information (Manila, 1955), which the senior author 
prepared late in 1954 and in early 1955. Labor laws are found in 
the Department of Labor’s Compilation of Effective Labor Legis¬ 
lation in the Philippines (Mimeographed, Manila, 1957). The 
history of the early labor movement is found in the issues of 
Muling Pagsilang, 1902. to 1908. A brief history of the labor 
movement is found m Emiliano Morabe’s “History of the Phil¬ 
ippine Labor Movement,” Department of Labor Yearbook, 
Volume I, No. 1 (Manila, 1949), and Bias F. Ople’s “The His¬ 
tory and Direction of Philippine Labor,” The Saturday Mirror 
Magazine, February 1, 1958. 
Economic nationalism is well expressed in a speech of Senator 
Claro M. Recto before the Manila Rotary Club on March 28,

1957, in Horacio Lava’s ‘‘Pattern for Progress,” The Manila 
Times Progress 1958, in the same author’s “The Colonial Structure 
of the Philippine Economy,” Comment, Second Quarter, 1958, 
and in the speeches of Dr. Jose Locsin, Chairman of the National 
Economic Council and of Marcelo S. Balatbat, President of the 
Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Manager of the NAMAR- 
CO, and later Secretary of Commerce, delivered at the Lyceum 
of the Philippines, October 2, 1959, in a forum on “Economic 
Nationalism.” The Bell Mission Report was published in book 
form by the Philippine Book Co., Manila, n. d. 
CHAPTER XXVIII 
Materials for contemporary history are numerous and need to 
be sifted. One of the most important sources of information is 
periodical literature, in the present instance, The Manila Chronicle, 
The Manila Times, The Daily Mirror, and other papers and maga¬ 
zines. The treaties and agreements concluded by the Philippines 
with foreign countries are found in the Department of Foreign Af¬ 
fairs’ Treaty Series, 4 volumes, the latest, as of May 1967, being 
Volume IV, No. 1, 1962-1964. An exposition of Philippine 
foreign policy is found in then Secretary of Foreign Affairs Carlos 
P. Romulo’s speech delivered at the Far Eastern University on 
May 25, 1951, and subsequently published in pamphlet form. 
Fundamentals of Our Foreign Policy (Manila, 1951). Excellent 
counterpoints to this policy are found in many speeches of 
Senator Claro M. Recto, particularly his “Our Asian Foreign 
Policy,” an address delivered at the Arellano University on April 
9, 1949, and “Our Mendicant Foreign Policy,” an address deliver¬ 
ed before the graduating class of the University of the Philippines 
on April 17, 1951. For a factual account of Philippine foreign 
relations, see Milton Walter Meyer’s A Diplomatic History of the 
Philippine Republic (Hawaii, 1965). The role of the Philippines in 
the United Nations is found in many issues of the official publica¬ 
tion of the UN, United Nations Bulletin, later on changed to 
United Nations Review, 1946 to date. Data on the SEATO are 
found in pamphlets issued by the SEATO headquarters at Bang¬ 
kok, Thailand, the most important of which are The SEATO 
Partnership (1956), The Manila Pact (USIS, n.d.), and SEATO: 
1954-1959 (Bangkok, n.d.). Communist advances in Asia are 
found in the daily papers, 1946 to date, and in Time Magazine, 
1949 to date. There are many good recent books on Southeast 
Asia, but those dealing with communist expansion in Korea,

611 
China, and Indo-China are, respectively, Rutherford M. Poats’ 
Decision in Korea (New York, 1954), F. F. Liu’s A Military 
History of Modern China, 1924-1949 (Princeton, 1956), and 
Ellen J. Hammer’s The Struggle for Indo-China Stanford, 1954). 
A perceptive analysis of the present struggle in Viet-Nam is found 
in Jean Locouture’s Vietnam: Between Two Truces (Vintage 
Book, New York, 1966). 
CHAPTER XXIX 
Contemporary accounts of the educational system of the 
Philippines and the criticisms leveled against it have been pub¬ 
lished in many magazines. Perceptive studies of that system are 
found in Alfredo T. Morales’ “Philippine Education, An Appraisal” 
and “The Crisis in Our Educational System,” published, respect¬ 
ively, in Progress 1957 and Progress 1959, and in Encamacion 
Alzona’s “Origins of Our Educational System,” Progress 1959. 
On community schools, the best sources so far are Juan C. Laya’s 
Little Democracies (Manila, 1951) and New Schools (Manila, 
1952); Six Community Schools of the Philippines (Manila, 1954): 
It can Be Done: Community Schools of the Philippines (Manila, 
1954); Florencio Fresnoza’s The Community School Training 
Center of Bayambang (Manila, 1954); The Community School 
of the Philippines (Manila, 1954); and Report of the United 
Nations Regional Community Development Conference for 
South East Asia (April, 1955). 
On language problem the best and most comprehensive writ¬ 
ing is that of Clifford H. Prator, Jr.’s Language Teaching in the 
Philippines (n. p., 1950). The contemporary literary situation is 
discussed in Leopoldo Y. Yabes’ “The State of Philippine Letters,” 
Progress 1959; Francisco Arcellana’s “The Literary Situation,” 
1958,” Progress 1958; and Valdemar Olaguer’s “The Literary Situ¬ 
ation,” Progress 1957. On the plastic arts, competent articles 
have been written by E. Aguilar Cruz, “Painters and People,” 
Progress 1957; Ricaredo Demetillo, “New Trends in Philippine 
Arts,” Progress 1958; and Galo B. Ocampo’s “Evolution of Philip¬ 
pine Art, Part II,” This Week, September 13, 1959. Contem¬ 
porary art and music are written about in the page of The Times 
Journal and Archipelago, particularly the articles of Emmanuel 
Torres, Leonidas V. Benesa, and Alfredo R. Roces (for art), and 
Vilma Santiago-Felipe and Rosalinda Orosa (for music).

CHAPTER XXX 
The sources for this chapter are mostly primary and may 
be found not only in contemporary newspapers and magazines, 
but in the official publications of the Government, among them 
the following: Vital Documents (National Media Production 
Center, n. d.), Vols. I to III; The Philippines Today (Department 
of Public Information); The Republic; Primer on Philippine 
Foreign Policy; Democratic Revolution; Basic Facts on Agrarian 
Reforms, etc. The daily newspapers Bulletin Today, Times 
Journal,* Daily Express, and others, are important sources of 
information on the “New Society”, for most, if not all, of the 
news about the government and what it does come from the 
Department of Information and other agencies of the govern¬ 
ment. 
CHAPTER XXXI 
There is a large and growing literature on the EDS A “Revo¬ 
lution,” of which the following may be considered interesting 
and useful: Nic" Joaquin, The Aquinos of Tarlac: An Essay on 
History as Three Generations (Manila, 1983); Lucy Komisar, 
Corazon Aquino: The Story of a Revolution (New York, 1987); 
Isabelo T. Crisostomo, Cory: Profile of a President (Quezon 
City, 1986); Cecilio Arillo, Breakway: The Inside Story of the 
Four Day Revolution in the Philippines (Mandaluyong, 1986): 
Bryan Johnson, Four Days of Courage. The Untold Story of the 
Fall of Ferdinand Marcos (Toronto, 1987), John Bresnan, ed., 
Crisis in the Philippines — The Ferdinand Marcos Era and Beyond 
(Princeton, 1986). People Power — An Eyewitness History (Manila, 
1986); Raymond Bonner, Waltzing with a Dictator: The Marcoses 
and the Making of American Policy (New York, 1987); and Sandra 
Burton, Impossible Dream: The Marcoses, The Aquinos, and the 
Unfinished Revolution (New York, 1989).

unwritten tews. The rilipino parent exercises 
almost absolute powers over the children. It is 
unthinkable for a Filipino to do an important 
thing without consulting his parents. The 
latter do not condone children talking back 
not only to them, but to those older than 
they are. 
The Filipino is naturally fatalistic. No 
amount of expostulation on the virtues of 
science or logic can dislodge him from his idea 
of fatalism. He believes that whatever happens 
to him is the work of Fate. This fatalism is 
best symbolized in the phrase "Baha/a na," a 
phrase that defies translation but which may 
be rendered loosely as "come what may." 
Loyalty to a friend or to a benefactor is 
one trait that is very strong in the Filipino. 
Do him a little favor and he remembers you 
to the end of his days. For to the Filipino, 
friendship is sacred and implies mutual help 
under any circumstances. A friend is expected 
to come to the aid not only of a personal 
friend, but also of the latter's family. A man's 
friend is considered a member of the family 
and is expected to share its tribulations as 
well as its prosperity and happiness. It is 
almost unthinkable for the Filipino to betray 
his friend, and if there be such one, he 
becomes a marked man: ostracism is the 
lightest punishment that can be meted out to 
him.

SOME OF PROFESSOR AGONCILLO'S BOOKS: 
• The Revolt of the Masses: The Story of Bonifacio and the 
Katipunan. Quezon City, University of the Philippines, 1956. 
"It is an unusually and refreshingly well written Philippine 
document." — DR. GILBERT S. PEREZ, poet, scholar, critic, and 
educator. 
"The Revolt of the Masses is a unified work of art. .. [It] is 
a distinctive contribution not only to Philippine historiography and 
historical literature but to Philippine literature itself." *— PROF 
LEOPOLDO Y. YABES, scholar and literary historian. 
• Malolos: The Crisis of the Republic. Quezon City, Univer¬ 
sity of the Philippines, 1960. 
"Agoncillo is no believer in objectivity, at least in the sense 
that names-and-dates historians interpret the word.... He is re¬ 
freshingly opinionated in a profession that is often namby-pamby 
for fear of arousing controversy, anger, or organized crusades which, 
if he depended for his living on an institution less liberal than the 
state university, could mean his expulsion from the classroom. 
"Shortly after The Revolt of the Masses came out an effort 
was made in certain quarters to link it with what has since been 
called 'legal and parliamentary Communism.' The academic witch- 
hunters failed, but they will doubtless try again after they have 
read Malolos which, more effectively than The Revolt, projects 
Agoncillo's overall view of the Philippine Revolution as a struggle 
between the 'Haves' and the 'Have nots.'" — EMILIO AGUILAR CRUZ, 
art critic, essayist, and editor. The Daily Mirror. 
"One great advantage of Agoncillo is that he writes with ease 
and distinction, being an accepted writer of note in English and in 
the national dialect_ He can therefore be extremely persuasive in 
his arguments because cf this literary quality of his writing. He 
interprets his characters wit!, feeling and the events of history in 
his hands take on the in vitability, in some instances, of a classical 
tragedy." -DR. PUR A SANTILLAN-CASTRENCE, essayist, critic, profes¬ 
sor, and diplomat. 
• The Fateful Ye»«rs: Japan's Adventure in the Philippines, 1941- 
1945. Quezon City, R. P. Garcia Publishing Co., 1965. Two volumes. 
"The work as a whole is a mine of information, every page 
is of interest, there is grim realism, relieved at times by humor, 
the tone is balanced and judicious.... the writing is clear and lively. 
— A. V. H. HARTENDORP, art connoisseur, critic, and magazine 
editor. 
"This is not a dry-as-dust account. Prof. Agoncillo has a vivid 
pen and an interesting style_ At last, twenty years after [the] 
events had taken place, a Filipino historian has come out with a 
two-volume work which vividly depicts the plight of the Filipinos 
and. their problems during those years of terror and hardship.... 
Prof. Agoncillo has made a definitely valuable contribution to 
pine historiography, a book which will be better appreciated ||g3C!U 
people with the passage of time." — CARLOS QUIRINO, biog r,
